text: And traces of pollutants such as chlorinated aromatics reach every spot on the globe; for example, dioxins are found in the tissues of Antarctic penguins.
Tertiary (advanced) treatment includes fi ltration of particulates from the microbial flocs of secondary treatment, and may include chemical processes to decrease nitrogen and phosphorus.
The fi nal step involves disinfection to eliminate pathogens, usually by a chemical process such as chlorination.
In the culture, organisms from the polluted site are cultivated repeatedly in the presence of added pollutant, and then tested for activity using radiolabeled substrates.

An example of successful bioremediation is the case of Aberdeen Proving Ground, where a microbial mat was used to catabolize chlorinated hydrocarbons left by weapons manufacture (eTopic 22.2).

How can we remediate industrial pollutants before they poison the local countryside and spread throughout the globe?
